page.title: 13Ecology
page.content: The non-residential areas are mainly used as intensively managed grassland. Two areas of deciduous woodland, Nansavallan Wood and Penpoll Wood are both Oak/Beech mixed woodland. Hedgerows are of the granite stone and earth Cornish hedge type, which have matured, with Elm and Hawthorn being well-represented. The disused railway track running from Penwethers junction to Newham is now unmanaged and reverting to woodland. Dogrose, Blackthorn and Holly are common. The estuary of the Truro river provides an extensive area of mud flat at low water and constitutes a winter feeding ground for a wide variety of wading birds. The National Trust land at Calenick, a silted stream bed, forms a wet area now largely undisturbed by man.
